Title: Fire at the titaniumoxide plant
EmergencyResponce_Descr: <p>Active extinguishing measures lasted 20 hours and there were 180 fire fighters working. The local resque service received help from surroundings.</p>

Site_Description:
<p>The plant is located in industrial park in Pori, Finland. The industrial park comprises of three other plants besides Huntsman (nowadays Venator P&amp;A Finland Oy). One is a power plant Porin Prosessivoima Oy, which provides energy also to Huntsman.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
Installation_Description: <p>Titanium dioxide (TiO2) pigments are produced from titanium, ilmenite ore and sulfuric acid (H2SO4). Also natrium hydroxid (NaOH) and hydrogen chloride (HCl) are used in process. Sulfuric acid is produced on site from elementary sulfur.</p>

Description:
<p>Chemicals did not play any part in fire itself, but were partly mixed in fire fighting water and ended to the bay of sea close to the industrial park.</p>
<p>Environmental causes were minimal: only lightly polluted fire fighting water for a short time.&nbsp;</p>

Causes_Description: <p>The ignition source could not be indentified definitely, but the ignition point was found out to be at electrical processgas filter. The spreading of the fire was made possible by open roof construction and process piping made of plastic. Due to power failure the fire fighting water could not be contained (pumped) as planned, which resulted some of the chemicals ending up to the sea.</p>

CausesHumans.ItemDescription: operator health (includes ailments, intoxication, death, etc.)
wilful disobedience/failure to carry out duties

CausesExternals.ItemDescription: utilities failure (electricity, gas, water, steam air, etc.)

Consequence_Description:
<p>The extensive roof and process pipelines of the titanium dioxide plant were burnt in particular. The middle part of the factory was completely destroyed. The financial damage amounted to tens of millions of euros in the&nbsp;fire. One fire fighter was slightly injured during the extinguishing operation. Environmental causes were minimal: only lightly polluted fire fighting water for a short time.&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;There was plans to build up the destroyed part a new, but the delays in rebuilding and the surpassing the cost estimate resulted to the decision to shut down the plant entirely.</p>
